holidays.name: National No Rhyme (Nor Reason) Day
holidays.description: Celebrate the mysterious side of language by honoring words and phrases that just don‚Äôt rhyme with anything else‚Äîno reason, no rhyme! Embrace the quirky oddities of English.
holidays.origin: Started as a playful acknowledgment of the difficulties poets and songwriters face trying to rhyme awkward words, this day was adopted by linguists and language lovers.
holidays.funFact: Despite its name, 'orange,' 'silver,' and 'purple' are famous words celebrated on this day for their lack of perfect rhymes.

holidays.name: Tattoo Removal Day
holidays.description: A day for those considering saying goodbye to a tattoo‚Äîwhether due to a change of heart or a new aesthetic direction!
holidays.origin: Coincides with the increasing popularity and accessibility of tattoo removal technology in the 21st century.
holidays.funFact: The most commonly removed tattoo is a name, highlighting how relationships can outlast ink!

holidays.name: National Cherry Popover Day
holidays.description: A delicious day dedicated to enjoying cherry popovers, delightfully airy pastries filled with sweet cherries, perfect for a breakfast treat or dessert.
holidays.origin: A culinary celebration created by baking enthusiasts in the U.S. to spotlight this lesser-known pastry variety.
holidays.funFact: Popovers owe their fluffy texture to steam puffing the batter; cherries just add a sweet surprise!

holidays.name: Beginning of Meteorological Autumn (Northern Hemisphere)
holidays.description: Mark the official start of meteorological fall, based on calendar months rather than the equinox, welcoming cooler weather and changing leaves.
holidays.origin: Meteorologists use this date for consistent seasonal statistics, differing from the astronomical autumn.
holidays.funFact: Meteorological seasons divide the year into four groups of three months each for easier climate comparison.
